Title:
Taxonomy and phylogeny of Meruliaceae with descriptions of
two new species from China
Keywords:
diversity, macrofungi, phylogenetic analysis, new taxa,
wood-rotting fungi
Abstract:
Two new wood-inhabiting fungi Hermanssonia fimbriata sp.
nov. and Phlebia austroasiana sp. nov in the family Meruliaceae are
described and illustrated from southwestern China based on molecular and
morphological evidence. The characteristics of Hermanssonia fimbriata
include annual, resupinate basidioma, a monomitic hyphal system, and
oblong ellipsoid basidiospores of 56 × 2.43 μm. Its basidioma changes
drastically upon drying, from being a light-coloured, juicy, with a very
papillose and wrinkled hymenophore, to dark-coloured and more or less
smooth hymenophore. The characteristics of Phlebia austroasiana include
annual, resupinate basidioma with clay-buff dry aculei, 23 aculei per
mm, a monomitic hyphal system, tubular cystidia of 2025 × 33.5 µm, and
oblong ellipsoid basidiospores of 4.45.2 × 2.13 μm. The phylogenetic
analyses based on the combined 2-locus dataset [ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (ITS) +
nuclear large subunit RNA (nLSU)] confirm the placement of two new
species respectively in Hermanssonia and Phlebia. Phylogenetically the
closely related species to the two new species are discussed.
